p: Spinel ferrites have a structure with the form MFe 2O 4, where M is a divalent cation and typically a transition metal. Oxygen (O 2â€“) ions form a face-centered cubic structure, Fe 3+ cations occupy half of the octahedral holes (h O), and M 2+ ions are placed in eight of the tetrahedral holes (h T). In particular, copper ferrite (CuFe 2O 4) has an inverse spinel structure, which has a different occupation of the vacancies: M 2+ cations are placed in h O with half of the Fe 3+ ions, whereas the other half are in h T.
